message: Today I opposed inclusion of major changes to the Ethics Office in the rules package that will govern House operations for the next two years. While I would support reasoned strengthening of the ethics process, I cannot support last-minute, major policy revisions without a thorough and public debate on the merits of reforms. I am thankful that President-elect Trump agreed and intervened.  House Leadership acted wisely when it withdrew the proposed Ethics Office changes.

As the 115th Congress begins its work, I’m grateful for the opportunity to tackle head-on the pressing issues the American people elected a unified Republican House, Senate, and President to address. I appreciate the trust that the citizens of North Alabama have placed in me. It’s a tremendous honor to continue serving the people of Alabama’s Fifth Congressional District.

Today Vice President-elect Mike Pence addressed the House Republican Conference saying “Priority #1” is keeping the promises Donald Trump made to the American people during the presidential campaign. While Congress has many pressing agenda items, repealing and replacing ObamaCare is the first order of business, and I look forward to voting to help the Trump Administration deliver its campaign promises.

The House just passed the Midnight Rules Relief Act which would give Congress the ability to overturn federal regulations rushed though in the last days of the outgoing Obama Administration. While growing federal regulations are nothing new, their number and cost have skyrocketed under the Obama Administration. I was glad to support this legislation to reclaim Congress’ legislative authority and curtail the influence of unelected bureaucrats whose regulations have stifled America's economy and burdened working families.

In the waning days of the outgoing Obama Administration, the United States failed to veto an anti-Israel United Nations resolution. This move is a dangerous violation of our longstanding, bipartisan friendship with Israel. Today I voted on House legislation to condemn and repeal the destructive resolution. Permitting the resolution to pass by “taking a walk” is harmful, counterproductive to peace, and emboldens those who wish to destroy Israel and murder Israelis.
While Alabama Football won't be bringing home the championship trophy, the team can be proud of their tremendous effort against Clemson and an exceptional season. #RollTide

I enjoyed visiting with Stephen Richardson of Decatur and congratulating him on being selected as a finalist to the American Trucking Associations' Captains of America’s Road Team, a national public outreach program that educates fellow motorists and the general public about safety and security on the highway. I wish him the best of luck as the association names team members tomorrow.

My friend and colleague, Senator Jeff Sessions, is a man of integrity and has a deep respect for the rule of law. He will restore support for America’s law officers, protect religious freedoms across the country, and enforce federal immigration law. I am appalled by unfounded attacks on his character and today attended Senator Sessions’ confirmation hearing to convey my unwavering support for his leadership in the Senate and future service to America as the next U.S. Attorney General. #ConfirmSessions

Today, the Center for Immigration Studies released a report highlighting the Obama Administration’s abysmal immigration enforcement numbers. Astoundingly, deportations of criminal aliens fell by nearly 3,000 in the last year, out of an estimated total population of 2 million criminal aliens. I was glad to join the conversation and discuss the opportunity America now has under the Trump Administration to take action on meaningful improvements to immigration policies and enforce the existing laws on our books, which President Obama unconstitutionally declined to enforce.

The House Armed Services Committee today passed a waiver, with my support, approving retired Marine General James “Mad Dog” Mattis for service as Secretary of Defense in President-elect Trump’s new administration. He is an outstanding, highly qualified selection. Gen. Mattis understands the complex threats facing our national security and will restore U.S. military readiness. He has received glowing endorsements across the military community in the Tennessee Valley, and I look forward to his strong leadership.

ObamaCare has forced American’s to endure skyrocketing premiums and declining health care quality. It is one of the biggest boondoggles and failures ever forced on the American people. Since ObamaCare’s passage, voters have sent a clear message that Big Brother bureaucrats have no business forcing Americans to buy health insurance we don’t want and we can’t afford. Today I will vote in support of a “Budget” that will be used as a procedural vehicle to strip the worst provisions from ObamaCare. Much work remains for Congress to repeal ObamaCare in its entirety, but today’s vote is a key first step.

As hundreds of Tennessee Valley residents prepare to travel to Washington, DC for the presidential inauguration Friday, here is a helpful article with information on navigating the city, including road and Metrorail station closures around the National Mall. I hope 5th District families enjoy their visit on this historic occasion and wish them safe travels to and from our nation’s capital.

I’m excited to welcome Reps. Rosa DeLauro, Martha Roby, and Tulsi Gabbard as Co-Chairs of the Army Aviation Caucus in the 115th Congress. The caucus provides a forum for Members of Congress, Congressional staff, and the Army to improve support and communication for Army aviation. I look forward to working closely with the caucus to reaffirm Congress’ bipartisan commitment to aviation readiness.
Getting ready for #Inauguration2017 as Alabamians drop by my office to pick up tickets for the ceremony tomorrow! I hope everyone in attendance enjoys this historic occasion. #ALinDC

Congratulations to Donald J. Trump, the 45th President of the United States! President Trump gave a great speech today, and I look forward to helping him fulfill his promises by voting on legislation to repeal ObamaCare, make Mexico pay for an impenetrable border security wall, and restore America’s military and international reputation to greatness.
ICYMI: I joined MSNBC last night to defend President Donald Trump against left-wing media attacks.
At the site of President Trump's historic inauguration celebrating with staff, family, America's next Attorney General Jeff Sessions and his wife Mary!

Martha and I considered it a good problem to have when on Saturday so many Alabamians joined our tour of the Capitol they couldn’t all fit into the group photo. I’m grateful for all the visiting Alabamians who made Friday’s inauguration and this weekend extraordinary, and I wish them all safe travels home.

Alabama’s Fifth Congressional District’s loss is President Donald Trump’s gain as my Legislative Counsel Peter J. White heads to the White House to serve as Senior Policy Analyst on the Domestic Policy Council. Peter hails from North Alabama and is a 2001 Grissom High School graduate. I wish him the best in this new position and commend his selection – President Trump is gaining an exceptional staffer.

The House just passed H.R. 7, with my support, to permanently ban taxpayer funded abortions. It is wrong to force all American taxpayers, at the point of a federal gun, to pay for other peoples’ abortions that, according to all medical and scientific evidence, take an innocent life.

We had a great turnout at the first meeting of the Army Aviation Caucus in the 115th Congress. I appreciate the insights shared by the six primary Army Aviation leaders on the important work carried out by our service members as well as the challenges facing Army Aviation readiness. Our caucus is getting to work to ensure this critical area of our armed forces receives the support needed to face the demands of an ever-changing global landscape.

I’m glad President Trump is quickly taking action to enforce our immigration laws, deport illegal aliens, and withhold federal funds from sanctuary cities. America is a nation of laws, first and foremost, and the President’s actions are a strong step toward restoring our country’s borders and broken immigration system.

I support temporarily pausing travel from terrorist-infested foreign countries until America’s refugee review process is strengthened to better protect Americans from the violence, murder, and mayhem that has become all too common in Europe, the Middle-East, and other parts of the globe.   No country on the planet allows as many foreign immigrants to permanently cross its borders as does America. However, and as the Department of Homeland Security states, “No foreign national in a foreign land . . . has any unfettered right to demand entry into the United States or to demand immigration benefits in the United States.”   Although it needs tweaking, I applaud President Trump’s executive order as a good first step that helps protect American citizens from torture and murder at the hands of Muslim fundamentalists.

Exciting news for the Tennessee Valley! Today Aerojet Rocketdyne announced plans to produce America’s newest advanced rocket engine, the AR1, in Huntsville, resulting in 100 new jobs. Production of the AR1 will mean the end of America’s reliance on Russian made RD-180 engines, assuring our access to space. Aerojet’s announcement is a great testament to North Alabama’s skilled workforce and capacity for high-tech manufacturing.

Today our nation joins together on NASA’s annual Day of Remembrance to honor the fallen crew members who lost their lives while furthering the pursuit of exploration and discovery. This year marks 50 years since the Apollo 1 tragedy on January 27, 1967, and we remember the lives and accomplishments of the fallen astronauts Gus Grissom, Ed White, and Roger Chaffee and their families. Though continuing to conquer space comes with great risk, the achievements for all mankind by these brave crews lead to unimagined advancement and inspire generations.  #NASARemembers

I have the utmost respect for Judge Gorsuch’s commitment and record of ruling on issues before his court based on rational interpretation of the original intent of the Constitution or law, regardless of his personal opinions. His commitment to this fundamental legal philosophy is essential to preserving the rule of law in our democratically elected representative government, and I look forward to his swift confirmation.
ICYMI: I joined MSNBC last night to discuss my support for Judge Neil Gorsuch, President Trump’s nominee to the Supreme Court.

Martha and I enjoyed spending time with members of the Medical Association of the State of Alabama during their visit to Washington.  I appreciate the insights shared by North Alabama doctors on the serious need to reduce Washington interference in healthcare, thereby improving patient care.

The Trump Administration today announced sanctions against 25 people and entities in response to Iran's latest ballistic missile test – which violated U.N. Security Council Resolution 2231. I strongly support this long-overdue action to put Iran on notice and denounce their destructive policies. President Obama's deeply flawed Iran nuclear deal made available billions Tehran could use to fund Islamic terrorism and effectively guarantees Iran will obtain nuclear weapons. I am thankful this Administration is holding accountable the world’s foremost state sponsor of terrorism whose stated goal is “Death to America.”
Ronald Reagan, the 40th president of the United States, was born #OTD in 1911. His legacy of leadership in America still inspires me today as I work to preserve his conservative values in Washington.

Although it should have come sooner, I am pleased the Senate confirmed Jeff Sessions as United States Attorney General. As I said following his confirmation hearings in early January, I have been fortunate to know Jeff Sessions for more than 20 years and admire him as a dedicated public servant of strong moral character, committed to upholding the rule of law. I appreciate Jeff Sessions’ willingness to serve and have every confidence he will faithfully defend the Constitution and protect the rights of all Americans.

I'm disappointed the 9th Circuit Court, often the most error-prone and reversed circuit court of appeal, ruled against President Trump’s Executive Order to temporarily restrict travel into the United States from countries designated as terrorist-infested by the previous Obama Administration.   A first year law student would have no trouble reading the law and quickly finding that President Trump has every legal right to protect Americans by issuing this national security Executive Order. Unfortunately, the 9th Circuit regularly hands down politically leftist, activist decisions.  Fortunately, their politically motivated orders are frequently reversed by the Supreme Court.

This week, the House passed two resolutions, with my support, to nullify rules adopted by the U.S. Department of Education in the final days of the Obama Administration. The House resolutions repeal education regulations that would establish onerous federal reporting requirements on local educators and impose federal standards for teachers, bypassing meaningful state standards.   By overturning these rules, Washington is providing flexibility and authority to local educators, parents, and teachers to enact education policies most suited to their communities. In my view, the federal government has no business dictating to local and state governments how to operate their K-12 schools.

One of the most enjoyable parts of representing Alabama’s Fifth District is calling high school students to inform them of their acceptance to a U.S. service academy and thank them for their willingness to serve our nation. I'm proud of these hard working students and congratulate them on their milestone achievement.

This morning, I enjoyed speaking to and taking questions from more than 400 attendees at the Annual Directed Energy Symposium, appropriately held in Huntsville. Redstone Arsenal has played a pioneering and pivotal role in the application of directed energy (electromagnetic radiation, lasers, and the like) as weapons. As a member of the Congressional Directed Energy Caucus, I will continue working to advocate and raise awareness for the national security applications of this technology in Congress.

My thoughts and prayers are with Congressman Rohrabacher’s 71 year old district director who was rendered unconscious when Democrat activists and anarchists swarmed the Congressman’s local office yesterday in an effort to coerce and intimidate Congressional action.   Congressman Rohrabacher's comments are worth reading. Burned cars, building arsons, and physical violence against American citizens are assaults on our republic that seriously threaten our nation's long history of civil discourse and honest disagreement. These acts have no place in America's republic.

ICYMI: I joined MSNBC to discuss possible investigations into Russian interference in the U.S. election and express my confidence in the Department of Justice to determine whether criminal activity occurred. More importantly, I am hopeful the Trump Administration and news media will focus on the critical issues America faces such as warnings from the Congressional Budget Office indicating that absent correction America will suffer a debilitating insolvency and bankruptcy should our national debt continue to soar higher year after year.

I was pleased to support continued work in the House today to dismantle Obama-era regulations by voting for legislation to nullify a rule which forces states to provide Title X federal grants to abortion providers. The regulation was a parting gift from the Obama Administration to Planned Parenthood, the nation’s largest abortion provider. Further, the rule undermines the 10th Amendment by eliminating the ability of states to prioritize Title X funds in the way that best serves their communities.

Thanks to the more than 5,000 North Alabamians who joined last night's Telephone Town Hall. I hope all participants found the call to be informative and productive. Due to time constraints I was unable to get to as many questions as I would have liked, but please go to my website at brooks.house.gov to learn more about my policy positions or to send me an email. You can also sign up for future Telephone Town Halls and my eNewsletter at the link below.

There is excitement and renewed commitment in Congress to ensuring America’s preeminence in space. I was pleased to meet with Marshall Space Flight Center Director Todd May this week and welcome hundreds of contractors and NASA representatives who support America’s space program to Washington. Human space flight inspires millions and stands as a beacon of human achievement, and as the Vice-Chair of the Subcommittee on Space I will continue supporting and reinvigorating America’s space program.

Today I joined Fox Business to discuss the push by conservatives in the House for a full repeal of ObamaCare, not ObamaCare-lite passed under the guise of a repeal bill. The American people deserve relief, and I’ll continue to urge House leadership to bring a vote on repealing the law in its entirety.

It was great to visit with SELEX Galileo employees today for a tour of their Huntsville facility and Q&A session. I enjoyed learning more about their commitment to strengthen America’s warfighters and mission success by developing airborne systems that enhance situational awareness, self-protection, and surveillance. Thanks for hosting me!

Thanks to Huntsville High School's Constitutional Conservatives Club for hosting me today for a lively conversation on current events and important political issues. It was great to talk with so many thoughtful and engaged students, particularly on the threat posed by the national debt and the need for a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution.

I enjoyed attending the Boy Scouts Spaghetti Dinner this evening in Huntsville. It was great to spend time with the Scouts of Troop 376 who serve our community and contribute to a more conscientious, responsible, and productive society.

Playing baseball was a highlight of my high school years, so I was glad to participate in the reunion Home Run Derby at Grissom, my alma mater. It was fun catching up with old teammates and getting in a few practice cuts in advance of this year's Congressional Baseball Game for charity.

I was pleased to recognize Shelby Vaughn, a senior at James Clemens High School in Madison, as the winner of the 2017 Congressional Art Competition for #AL05 in a special award ceremony at the Huntsville Museum of Art yesterday. Her colored pencil entry entitled “Joy” will be displayed at the U.S. Capitol for one year, alongside winning submissions from other Congressional districts. Congratulations to Shelby and the honorable mentions from the Fifth District for their hard work and artistic vision!

Thank you to Morgan County Commissioners Ray Long and Randy Vest for dropping by my Washington office today to say hello. As a former county commissioner, I deeply appreciate the important work of local officials and their dedicated service to our communities.

President Trump delivered a great speech tonight! I enjoyed his optimistic tone and message of strength and unity across America. I’m glad the President committed to restarting America’s economic engine and fixing our broken immigration system. I look forward to working with my colleagues in Congress to support President Trump’s bold vision for our nation.
I joined MSNBC to discuss how Congress can work with President Trump on the major issues he addressed in his speech last night and tackle the overriding issue in Washington, our national debt.

The February edition of my newsletter, The Brooks Report, went out this week to nearly 14,000 individuals across #AL05. I believe it is important to keep you up to date with what I’m doing in D.C. and the Tennessee Valley, and if you would like to subscribe to receive future newsletters, you can do so here: brooks.congressnewsletter.net

As a former prosecutor, I can vouch that prosecutors are like all other Americans in that we have friends, financial interests, political supporters and the like. When any of those interests are investigated, it is appropriate for a prosecutor to recuse himself to avoid even the appearance of impropriety. I did it as Madison County District Attorney. Luther Strange did it as Alabama Attorney General. Recusals are quite common among prosecutors. As such, I am proud that Attorney General Jeff Sessions did the right thing by recusing himself just in case there is ever sufficient evidence to warrant an investigation of the Trump Campaign for President.  Apparently recusal is not enough for some hyper-partisan Democrats. To those Democrats I say this: Get over it. Your side lost the election. Your conduct embarrasses yourself and your country. America needs you to stop whining and act in a bipartisan manner for the good of our country to help overcome America’s border security, health care, debt and other challenges.  I have known Jeff Sessions for more than two decades. Jeff Sessions is one of the most honorable men I've ever known. It is a shame that a great man like Jeff Sessions must endure scurrilous, hyper-partisan attacks in order to do the job America needs its Attorney General to do.

Thanks to the Chamber of Commerce of Huntsville/Madison County for hosting me today for an annual update on the latest from Washington. I enjoyed addressing the more than 800 in attendance and taking questions. As I highlighted today, Congress must meaningfully address America’s unsustainable long-term fiscal path. As your representative, I refuse to ignore economic realities and will continue to support pro-growth trade, tax, and regulatory reform to revitalize the American economy.

I was pleased the House passed the NASA Authorization Act of 2017 this evening which creates the long-term stability and continuity of purpose NASA needs to accomplish its robust missions, including the Space Launch System and Orion Spacecraft. The legislation affirms America’s commitment to human spaceflight and the #JourneytoMars. I will continue to support NASA and work to reinvigorate America’s space program.

I joined Chuck Todd on MSNBC this afternoon to raise questions about the GOP’s heath care bill. As I see it, this is the largest Republican welfare program ever proposed. While we do not yet have a Congressional Budget Office score for the plan, I have serious concerns that this legislation will cost the federal government funds we have to borrow and cannot afford to pay back. Quite frankly, the serious national security threat posed by America’s exploding national debt and deficits must be our number one priority. Further, as a believer in the 10th Amendment, health care should be left to the states to decide. If a state wants Obamacare, that is fine – provided they can shoulder the cost.

Great to visit with 8th graders from Randolph School in Huntsville this morning at the U.S. Capitol. I appreciated all of their insightful questions and enjoyed our discourse on a range of issues. I hope the rest of their visit to Washington is educational and fun!

Today, with my strong support, the House passed the Department of Defense Appropriations Act. The highest priority of the federal government is America’s national security, and this bill includes a 2.1% pay raise for our service men and women, reverses the Obama Administration’s drawdown of troops, and includes increases in key priorities for the Redstone Arsenal community. I urge the Senate to quickly take up this legislation and send a clear message of commitment to our military members.

Federal policy that supports our farmers is a priority of mine in Congress given agriculture’s importance to Alabama’s economy. I was glad to sit down and discuss issues like over-regulation and tax policy with members of the Alabama Farmers Federation from #AL05 today.

Enjoyed touring the Capitol with students from the Ardmore High School Marching Tigers this morning. It was great spending time with so many bright and engaged young people interested in the history of our nation, and I hope they have a good rest of their visit to Washington.

I was grateful for the opportunity to address the almost 200 guests in attendance at the National Federation of the Blind 2017 Convention and welcome attendees to Huntsville. This convention is the largest gathering of the blind in the State of Alabama, and I was proud to affirm NRF’s mission and express my support for the hopes and dreams of the nation’s blind.

Today I joined Fox News and affirmed my commitment to deliver a clean repeal of ObamaCare to the American people. In my judgment, once ObamaCare is repealed, we need to inject competition into the marketplace, eliminate the antitrust laws which promote oligopolies and monopolies, and turn health care over to the states in the form of block grants.

As the Vice-Chairman of the Space Subcommittee, I was pleased to welcome the more than 100 suppliers represented at the 2017 United Launch Alliance Supplier Conference in Washington, and congratulate the ULA team on their 117th successful launch since the company was formed in December 2006. Alabama’s Fifth District is proud to have ULA in Decatur and support their continued work on national security and maintaining America’s access to space.

Thanks to all the #AL05 families and students who braved the snowy weather today for an early morning tour of the Capitol with me and my wife Martha! We were glad to visit with so many North Alabamians and were pleased to see so many students on Spring Break take an interest in our nation’s history and government. Wishing everyone safe travels home.

Great to visit with members of the Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) from across Alabama today. I appreciated their insight on important issues like healthcare and family leave legislation. In my view, a free-market approach is the best way forward and protects the vital competition that has made America's economy the strongest in the world.

This morning, I joined MSNBC to express my support for President Trump’s revised immigration Executive Order and talk about the Republican healthcare bill, which in my view amounts to the largest Republican welfare program ever proposed. The Constitution clearly grants President Trump absolute authority on matters of admitting foreigners to America, and I encourage the President to appeal the decisions of overreaching federal judges who have unconstitutionally blocked his efforts to ensure our national security.

America’s veterans deserve the best we have to offer and their Constitutional rights safeguarded. I was proud to support House passage of legislation this week to protect veterans’ Second Amendment Rights and ensure the Veterans Affairs Administration serves our veterans effectively.

Today is an exciting day for America’s space program! As the Representative for NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center, I was honored to join President Trump at the White House today for the signing of the NASA Authorization Act. This legislation creates the long-term stability and continuity of purpose NASA needs to accomplish its robust missions, including the Space Launch System and Orion Spacecraft. In signing this legislation, President Trump demonstrated his strong support for NASA and reaffirmed America’s commitment to human spaceflight and the journey to Mars.

I will vote against the House GOP healthcare/welfare plan this week because it does not deliver on the promise I made to Alabamians to deliver a clean repeal of Obamacare. Instead, this legislation creates a huge new welfare program. Over the long haul that’s going to result in either higher premiums, higher taxes, or greater deficit and debt that’s going to burden our economy for decades to come.

I will vote against the American Health Care Act because it has more bad policy than any bill I have ever faced. I simply cannot, and will not, vote for bad legislation that hurts so many Americans solely because Washington friends and colleagues ask me to.

I introduced a simple, two-page bill to achieve a clean repeal of ObamaCare. The recently defeated healthcare proposal to amend ObamaCare left much of the framework of the disastrous law intact and would have resulted in higher premiums for struggling American families. The path forward on health care does not have to include the permanency of ObamaCare. Republicans sent a bill to repeal ObamaCare to the President’s desk in 2015 so the votes are there to deliver on the promise of a full repeal to the American people. I will continue fighting in Congress to find a path forward that will lower premiums, not raise them. Delivering a clean repeal is the best place to start.

Great to spend time with students from Liberty Middle School this morning! Martha and I enjoyed showing them some of our favorite spots around the Capitol building. We truly hope it was a worthwhile and informative experience and that y’all enjoy the rest of your trip.
I joined Fox Business this morning to discuss the way forward on healthcare and how the House can quickly pass constructive legislation to deliver a clean repeal of ObamaCare.

Transparency and reproducibility are hallmarks of solid science. I was pleased the House today passed the HONEST Act, with my support, to bar the EPA from using secret science to justify costly regulations that burden our economy. This legislation will ensure the basis for regulatory decisions are founded in data available to the public.

Securing America’s borders has long been a priority of mine in Congress. I fully support President Trump’s effort to build a southern border wall and have Mexico pay for it. In keeping with this objective, I am pleased to be an original cosponsor of Congressman Mike Rogers’ legislation, the Border Wall Funding Act, to impose a 2% tax on remittances sent south of the border, raising nearly $500 million per year from Mexico alone for construction of the wall.

Russia has repeatedly breached the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty by deploying missile systems that violate the agreement. Today, in a House Armed Services Committee hearing I questioned a panel of witnesses on the implications of these Russian actions and potential options for a U.S. response to violations.

I was pleased to take part in this morning’s ribbon cutting for Huntsville Botanical Garden’s new Guest Center. The garden has grown significantly since its opening in 1988, and I’m thankful for the dedication of volunteers, members, supporters, and donors who through their hard-work and resources contribute to our vibrant community by making possible a first-class public garden. The new facility will serve as a welcome center with expanded meeting, reception, and wedding spaces and is now open to the public.

The Tennessee Valley can take pride in having one of the best-run airports in the country. According to U.S. Department of Transportation data compiled by the American City Business Journal, Huntsville International Airport is among the top 20 best-run airports in America, beating out many larger airports for the spot and coming in at #1 in the state!

Last night, I met with Vice President Pence and suggested a compromise to garner support in the House Freedom Caucus for the American Health Care Act.   Notwithstanding the many provisions in the health care bill with which I strongly disagree, as a compromise, I will vote for the bill in its current form if a States Rights’ amendment is added that gives states the authority to determine the content and coverages in health insurance policies issued to its citizens. Hence, a state, not the federal government, shall decide whether its health insurance policies will include Essential Health Benefits.  Those states that want expensive policy requirements can have them, provided they are willing to pay the accompanying higher premium costs. If the White House and the rest of the House GOP Conference will agree to this very constructive, cost-reducing, States' Rights measure, I will vote for the American Health Care Act.

Congress has an opportunity to work with the Trump Administration to ensure that our nation’s immigration laws are strictly enforced. It is long past time the House use the power of the purse to defund cities and localities who have refused to comply with federal immigration laws and knowingly shield dangerous felons from removal by ICE. According to an ICE report from March of 2017, there are an estimated 300 cities and counties obstructing federal immigration agents from doing their jobs to deport dangerous criminals, thereby intentionally endangering Americans.

ICYMI: I joined Lou Dobbs to discuss the progress being made among House Republicans and the White House on healthcare legislation and how best to lower health insurance premiums for the American people.

Thanks to fifth graders and parents from Tanner School for braving the rainy weather in Washington this morning to join me and Martha for a tour of the U.S. Capitol. I enjoyed fielding some great questions from students about why I became a Congressman and how often I get back to the State of Alabama to visit with my grandkids. We wish the group a wonderful rest of their visit to Washington and safe travels back home.

President Trump delivered on his promise of an outstanding #SCOTUS nominee, and I commend Neil Gorsuch’s confirmation as the next associate justice of the United States Supreme Court. Despite failed partisan attempts aimed to paint Gorsuch as an ideologue who will rule based on personal beliefs, Gorsuch has consistently demonstrated his commitment and record of ruling on issues before his court based on rational interpretation of the original intent of the Constitution or law. I'm certain Gorsuch will honor the legacy of Justice Antonin Scalia.

Thanks very much to St. John Paul II Catholic High School for the warm welcome today. I enjoyed visiting with teachers and answering questions from AP Government students. Hopefully some of the answers I provided were helpful - best of luck on your upcoming AP exam!
I enjoyed spending time with Whitesburg Baptist’s lunch group today, and I appreciated the opportunity to hear from them on issues important to seniors in North Alabama.

I appreciated Sanmina-SCI hosting me this afternoon for an informative product demonstration and tour of their Huntsville facility. It was great to visit with the dedicated employees and see the array of sophisticated electronic equipment manufactured here in the Tennessee Valley.

More exciting news for North Alabama! Aerojet Rocketdyne today announced they are bringing an estimated 800 positions to Huntsville. I am grateful for their continued investment and commitment to the community, and I’m hopeful it's a harbinger of future prosperity!

Downtown Decatur will soon have a first-rate educational destination and cultural venue in the Cook Museum of Natural Science. Today, I toured the nearly completed facility and learned about the collections and programs in store for future visitors. I am thankful for the committed individuals who made this project possible, and I look forward to seeing the museum once it is complete.

The Arc of Madison County, Inc.- Jane K. Lowe Center is a testament to the ingenuity and generosity of North Alabamians. During my visit today, I had the opportunity to meet men and women of the Arc and the staff who have made it their life's work to create a place where people with intellectual disabilities can thrive. It was great to see firsthand the positive impact this organization has on our community.

Thanks to Intuitive Research and Technology Corporation for hosting me today for a Q&A session! It was great to learn more about the exciting virtual reality projects being developed and visit with employees.

This afternoon, I enjoyed holding a town hall with employees at BASF's Huntsville facility, where they develop emission-control technologies for a variety of applications. I appreciate BASF hosting me and all the great questions on the latest from Washington.

The new location of Practical Energetics Research, LLC is now open! I was pleased to attend the ribbon cutting yesterday and meet the folks at PER who develop and manufacture high-capability weapons systems for America’s military.
May you and your family know the joy of everlasting life. Happy Easter!

Broadband internet access is the infrastructure issue of the 21st Century. This morning’s announcement by AT&T and the Limestone County Economic Development Association that Breeding Industrial Park, Elm Industrial Park and Southpoint Business Park are now fiber ready is great news for North Alabama. This will give the area the capability to attract high-tech firms that require superfast internet speeds to operate, and I look forward to seeing the job and economic growth that will result.

Congratulations to Robert Monette (pictured second from the left) from Madison, Alabama for receiving the Silver Star Medal, one of our nation’s highest military honors. Throughout his impressive Army career, Mr. Monette showed a selfless desire to help others. During the Vietnam War at the Battle of An Loc, he braved heavy ground fire and saved many fellow soldiers. Despite all the circumstances that would have justified retreat, he persevered, unconcerned for his own life. Mr. Monette is truly a great example of dedication and selflessness for every American. Please join me in thanking him for his service.

I applaud President Trump’s Buy American and Hire American Executive Order that strengthens Buy American laws and implements much needed reforms to our guest-worker program. With underemployment rates near 10%, stagnant wages, and all net job gains over the last 14 years going to foreigners, America can ill-afford to continue policies that favor foreign manufacturers and foreign workers over American citizens. President Trump’s efforts to strengthen protections against fraud and abuse in the H-1B program and maximize the use of goods, products, and materials produced here at home is a positive step toward putting America back on track.

Congratulations to Raina Verser of New Century Technology High School on representing Alabama in the Poetry Out Loud: National Recitation Contest Finals in Washington, DC for the second year running. I enjoyed visiting with Raina and her family today and hope to see Raina compete again next year as a senior.

Thanks to improvements fought for and obtained by the House Freedom Caucus, I will vote for and support the amended American Health Care Act that partially repeals ObamaCare while driving down health insurance costs for millions of Americans. After the House Freedom Caucus sought and was denied a vote to totally repeal ObamaCare, the caucus worked tirelessly and used its political muscle to negotiate and successfully force conservative and States’ Rights changes to the AHCA. Despite these conservative advances, there is still much to be done, and I am committed to working with my Senate colleagues to deliver on our promises to the American people to provide relief from the damaging effects of ObamaCare.

Martha and I enjoyed hosting Madison Academy 5th graders at the U.S. Capitol for a tour yesterday evening and were grateful for the opportunity to field great questions about the U.S. Congress. Many thanks to this impressive group of students and safe travels back to Alabama.

This week, I introduced legislation to reform the abused Temporary Protected Status (TPS) program. The TPS program was established as a temporary immigration status granted as a result of a natural disaster or other extraordinary condition. However, “Temporary” Protected Status is de facto permanent, as under current law, it is almost certain to be repeatedly renewed. Years and sometimes decades later, long after the extraordinary conditions have passed, hundreds of thousands of foreign residents remain in the U.S. under TPS status. My bill would ensure that temporary means temporary and provide much needed reform for what has become a long-running amnesty program.

HHS released a sobering report on premium hikes for Americans due to ObamaCare taxes, regulations, and mandates. According to the report, nationwide individual market premiums increased 105% – meaning health insurance premium costs more than doubled. In Alabama, health insurance cost increased a staggering and obscene 223%.   When people ask me why I insist on a full repeal of ObamaCare, a 223% hike in health insurance premium costs says it all. That’s why I stood strong in the face of fierce headwinds and criticism, and fought so hard to successfully amend the original Republican healthcare bill so that it will decrease premiums, not increase them on already overburdened and stressed Alabama families.

Today, President Trump delivered on a key component of his "America first" agenda with the unveiling of the RAISE Act to modernize America’s outdated, legal immigration system. Our immigration system, which is by far the most generous system on the planet, favors low-skilled immigrants, thereby depressing wages and harming our most vulnerable citizens.    The RAISE Act replaces the current permanent employment-visa framework with a skills-based system that rewards applicants based on their individual merits. Further, the legislation eliminates the diversity visa lottery as well as the immigration preferences for extended family and adult family members of U.S. residents, also known as "chain migration".   America must recognize our challenges and opportunities, and be much more selective in our immigration policies to ensure incoming immigrants are both self-sufficient and are able and willing to be properly absorbed into American society. If we aren’t, American workers will continue to have their wages undercut by the importation of cheap, foreign labor and America will lose its special place in history.

Today the House passed the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, or Micah's Law, which protects unborn children from gruesome late-term abortion. Micah’s Law is named after Micah Pickering from Iowa City, Iowa, who was born prematurely at 22 weeks. Micah is now five years old and living a normal life.  Scientific studies have conclusively demonstrated that, at the 20-week mark, an unborn child can hear music, feel pain, and survive outside its mother’s womb. Micah's Law gives more children like Micah Pickering the opportunity to experience life and ends the practice of painfully killing unborn children who, if given the chance, can live a healthy life.

I strongly support President Trump’s call today to end harmful visa lottery and chain migration policies. That’s why earlier this year I cosponsored both the SAFE for America Act and the Immigration in the National Interest Act to reform chain migration policies and eliminate the visa lottery, which allocates 55,000 visas per year for no justifiable reason.  These measures would replace our broken immigration system with policies that are merit-based. America has by far and away the most generous immigration system on the planet, but we only accept between 5-12% of immigrants based on education and skill level. I encourage my colleagues to quickly take up these important, common-sense reforms.

This week the Department of Homeland Security extended Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Honduras. Although TPS was created to be temporary, it has been running on autopilot for decades providing de facto amnesty to hundreds of thousands of workers throughout the country. Honduras and Nicaragua were originally given protected status following Hurricane Mitch in 1998. Since then, unelected bureaucrats have rubber stamped extensions without oversight from Congress. That’s why earlier this year I introduced legislation to reform this badly broken system. My bill would restore proper oversight to Congress and set strict but reasonable limits for how long we provide other countries protections following disaster.
